required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Prospective, Randomized, Controlled, Multicenter, Pivotal, Clinical Investigation Evaluating the Safety and Efficacy of HEMOBLAST Bellows in Cardiothoracic, Abdominal, and Orthopedic Lower Extremity Surgeries

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this prospective, randomized, controlled study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a new hemostatic device (HEMOBLAST™ Bellows) compared to a control device, absorbable gelatin sponge USP with thrombin.

primary_outcome.description: The proportion of subjects achieving hemostasis at 6 minutes post-hemostat application was calculated. Hemostasis was defined as a grade of 0 (None/Dry) on the Surface Bleeding Severity Scale, with additional grades, ranging from 1 (Minimal/Oozing) to 5 (Extreme/Gushing), considered a failure of hemostasis.

secondary_outcome.description: The average time from the opening of the package to the product being ready to use, measured in minutes and seconds.
The proportion of subjects achieving hemostasis at 3 minutes post-hemostat application was calculated

arm_group.description: Absorbable gelatin sponge, USP with thrombin

intervention.intervention_name: Absorbable gelatin sponge, USP with thrombin

facility.name: Columbia University Medical Center / New York Presbyterian Hospital
Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Intermountain Liver Disease and Transplant Center

participant_flow.recruitment_details: First subject completed follow-up: August 19, 2016 Last patient completed follow-up: January 18, 2017
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Subject enrollment occurred after the subject met preoperative eligibility criteria, gave written informed consent, and met intraoperative eligibility criteria. Subjects were randomized and treated subsequent to enrollment. Subjects could withdraw or be withdrawn from the study at any time after enrollment, including prior to treatment.

group.title: Control
group.description: Absorbable gelatin sponge, USP with thrombin Absorbable gelatin sponge, USP with thrombin

group.title: Control
group.description: Absorbable gelatin sponge, USP with thrombin

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: Proportion of Subjects Achieving Hemostasis
outcome.description: The proportion of subjects achieving hemostasis at 6 minutes post-hemostat application was calculated. Hemostasis was defined as a grade of 0 (None/Dry) on the Surface Bleeding Severity Scale, with additional grades, ranging from 1 (Minimal/Oozing) to 5 (Extreme/Gushing), considered a failure of hemostasis.
outcome.population: The efficacy analysis population was defined as the Time-To-Hemostasis (TTH) population and included all subjects who were randomized, received study intervention, and had a TTH assessment recorded.

group.title: Control
group.description: Absorbable gelatin sponge, USP with thrombin

measure.title: Proportion of Subjects Achieving Hemostasis
measure.description: The proportion of subjects achieving hemostasis at 6 minutes post-hemostat application was calculated. Hemostasis was defined as a grade of 0 (None/Dry) on the Surface Bleeding Severity Scale, with additional grades, ranging from 1 (Minimal/Oozing) to 5 (Extreme/Gushing), considered a failure of hemostasis.
measure.population: The efficacy analysis population was defined as the Time-To-Hemostasis (TTH) population and included all subjects who were randomized, received study intervention, and had a TTH assessment recorded.

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: The primary endpoint was designed to establish comparable efficacy based upon a non-inferiority margin of 10% for the difference in the probability of TTH within 6 minutes comparing HEMOBLAST™ to G+T (HEMOBLAST™– G+T). Letting θ denote the true difference in the probability of hemostasis at 6 minutes between HEMOBLAST™ to G+T, the trial will test the null hypothesis H0: θ ≤ -0.10 vs. the alternative hypothesis HA : θ > -0.10 using a one-sided level 0.025 test.
analysis.method_desc: Stratified adjustments for surgery type were made using the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel weighting.

analysis.groups_desc: A secondary endpoint of superiority of HEMOBLAST relative to G+T for success at achieving hemostasis within 6 minutes was evaluated.
analysis.p_value_desc: Adjustment for mulitple comparisons were made when assessing secondary endpoints using a fixed sequence closed testing procedure to control the family-wise type I error rate at 0.05

outcome.title: Product Preparation Time
outcome.description: The average time from the opening of the package to the product being ready to use, measured in minutes and seconds.
outcome.population: The efficacy analysis population was defined as the Time-To-Hemostasis (TTH) population and included all subjects who were randomized, received study intervention, and had a TTH assessment recorded.

group.title: Control
group.description: Absorbable gelatin sponge, USP with thrombin

measure.title: Product Preparation Time
measure.description: The average time from the opening of the package to the product being ready to use, measured in minutes and seconds.
measure.population: The efficacy analysis population was defined as the Time-To-Hemostasis (TTH) population and included all subjects who were randomized, received study intervention, and had a TTH assessment recorded.

analysis.groups_desc: The difference in mean preparation time was tested using a linear regression model with stratified adjustment for surgery type.
analysis.p_value_desc: Adjustment for mulitple comparisons were made when assessing secondary endpoints using a fixed sequence closed testing procedure to control the family-wise type I error rate at 0.05

outcome.title: Proportion of Subjects Achieving Hemostasis
outcome.description: The proportion of subjects achieving hemostasis at 3 minutes post-hemostat application was calculated
outcome.population: The efficacy analysis population was defined as the Time-To-Hemostasis (TTH) population and included all subjects who were randomized, received study intervention, and had a TTH assessment recorded.

group.title: Control
group.description: Absorbable gelatin sponge, USP with thrombin

measure.title: Proportion of Subjects Achieving Hemostasis
measure.description: The proportion of subjects achieving hemostasis at 3 minutes post-hemostat application was calculated
measure.population: The efficacy analysis population was defined as the Time-To-Hemostasis (TTH) population and included all subjects who were randomized, received study intervention, and had a TTH assessment recorded.

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: The difference in the probability of hemostasis within 3 minutes was tested using a logistic regression model with stratified adjustment for surgery type.
analysis.p_value_desc: Adjustment for multiple comparisons when assessing secondary endpoints was performed using a fixed sequence closed testing procedure to control the family-wise type I error rate at 0.05.

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: The difference in the probability of hemostasis within 3 minutes was tested using a logistic regression model with stratified adjustment for surgery type.
analysis.p_value_desc: Adjustment for multiple comparisons when assessing secondary endpoints was performed using a fixed sequence closed testing procedure to control the family-wise type I error rate at 0.05.

reported_events.time_frame: Enrollment until completion of 6-week follow-up visit
reported_events.desc: All adverse events (AEs) through final follow-up were collected. An AE is defined according to the European Standard EN ISO 14155 as ‘any untoward medical occurrence in a subject.’ An AE related to a device (adverse device effect, ADE) is defined as ‘any untoward and unintended response to an investigational medical device.’

group.title: Control
group.description: Absorbable gelatin sponge, USP with thrombin

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Rachel Hoffman, Vice President Clinical Operations North America
